captions.text:
We know that fire results from the combustion
of organic material and air, but don't you

still sometimes wonder what fire is? Why are
gas flames blue and wood-fire orange? And

why do flames move in such a mesmerizing way?
Chemistry may tell us the recipe for combustion,
but the light show is all physics.

When a flame burns cleanly (like a gas flame,
blowtorch or the base of a candle), the heat

excites the molecules to release light (usually
pale-blue) from atomic transitions. That's

Now when the fuel isn't as pure and doesn't
entirely burn (like a wood or coal fire or

the top of a candle flame), there's still
some blue light, but you don't see it because

it's overpowered by light from all the particles
of soot & smoke - they're glowing red-hot!

So why do hot objects glow? Thermodynamics.
A process called "blackbody radiation" makes

all objects glow with light of a color depending
on their temperature. The reason that you

don't see your friends glowing, though, is
because we're too cool to glow with visible

light - we glow in infrared. But lava, a hot
piece of iron, or soot in a flame are all

hot enough to glow with that familiar red-orange
light.

And the reason flames are shaped like tongues
snaking skywards? Gravity! The earth's pull

is what makes hot air rise, and this convection
shapes flames into their familiar form. If

you light a match in zero-G, the flame spreads
outwards like a balloon - there's nothing

to tell it which way to go, so it goes in
all directions!

comments.author: Dylan Hayes

comments.text:
As it's been said, fire is not a thing; rather it is an event. This is why 
you cannot capture and hold a flame. Same is true for electricity. It's 
nothing more than the flow of electrons. Thus you simply can't have a 
container of electricity.

This is important to know because it takes the mystery out of fire as to 
why you just can't seem to get a handle on it. Nothing more than the 
heat/light of a short lived chemical reaction.﻿

comments.author: Zero Cool

comments.text:
+Zero Cool I want to believe I understood your question. First of all, 
let's remember what gravity is. Gravity is one of the four fundamental 
forces and a general property of matter, which means that all matter exerts 
a gravitational force on other matter. Right now, I am exerting a 
gravitational force on you,and so is the Earth and even a far away galaxy. 
However, because my mass is insignificant compared to that of the Earth, 
you can only feel Earth's strong pull. Now, if you recall the equation to 
calculate the force of gravity between to bodies you will see that the 
farther they are, the lesser their pull is. In the hypothetical case that 
you were in outer space at a considerable distance from any huge amount of 
matter, your body would wander slowly in space, and I say slowly because 
there will still be a faint pull, which is the resultant of the sum of all 
the gravitational forces exerted on you. If you wanted to experience real 
zero gravity, you woukd need to place YOUR CENTER OF MASS in the only point 
in the universe where the sum of all gravity forces sum up to zero. I hope 
I answered your question. If not, GO FUND YOURSELF XD if you know what I 
mean.
comments.author: Arturo Gallegos

comments.text:
+zeke1220​ Yeah, in space station, 90% of gravity that affects us affects 
them as well. Still, at the speed of 28000 km/h if I am not mistaken, they 
are basically in free fall all the time- hence lack of gravity. Zero 
gravity then means that gravity doesn't exist at all. ﻿

Thanks for answering.
comments.author: Zero Cool

comments.text:
+Zero Cool Zero-G is a lack of acceleration accompanied by a lack of normal 
force exertion. afaik, there's no such thing as zero gravity

comments.author: Iain MacLean (Radioactive Yeti)

comments.text:
+Iain MacLean Centrifugal and gravitational forces can balance so it's in 
equilibrium. Planets stay in orbit for billions of years without spiralling 
inward.
comments.author: RedInferno112

comments.text:
+RedInferno112 Yes, but everything in orbit eventually falls back down to 
Earth, kind of like water going down a drain. Also, horizontal velocity 
doesn't eliminate the gravitational pull of Earth. In fact, it needs the 
gravitational pull of Earth to come back around again.
comments.author: Iain MacLean (Radioactive Yeti)

comments.text:
+Iain MacLean Yes, but forces that small are almost immeasurable. Orbit is 
exactly my point, the centrifugal force eliminates the gravitational force 
from Earth or whatever celestial body being orbited.
comments.author: RedInferno112

comments.text:
+RedInferno112
Gravity is still acting on things in orbit. It just might not feel or look 
like it because they are falling really fast. Also, gravity happens even on 
an atomic scale, so technically the vessel would always be pulling on 
itself.
comments.author: Iain MacLean (Radioactive Yeti)

comments.text:
+Iain MacLean Theoretically it is possible, if the vessel the experiment 
was conducted on had a certain orbital speed and altitude (including the 
lagrangian compensation for other astronomical objects), than theoretically 
zero gravity can be acheived.

so when he refers to the flame as what a flame does in zero gravity, he's 
right, even if it isn't actually.
comments.author: Ryan Denziloe

comments.text:
+Ryan Denziloe
You are right if you're referencing that there is no difference between 
being in a box that's in constant free fall than in a box with no gravity 
at all. The laws of physics applies exactly the same way, that's 
relativity, but that doesn't mean the gravity isn't affecting them. All 
this means is that the g-force inside the box is the same as if there was 
no gravity at all. Now, if gravity were not affecting the box and all of 
the people inside, then they would head out in a straight line to deep 
space, but since gravity is clearly affecting them while they remain in 
constant free fall, then they must be following an orbit.

Tl;dr They experience normal gravity, they're still just in free fall. 
Relativity confirms that they experience the same laws of physics.
comments.author: Drednaught

comments.text: +Drednaught Technically there's no difference. See: general relativity.

comments.text:
I took fire engineering and my prof would always correct us when we would 
say that heat rises, because it doesn't. Heat doesn't defy gravity and 
lift, rather the cooler denser air pushes it upwards. We always did think 
that prof was a bit anal lol. ﻿
comments.author: Matthew Di Bartolomeo

comments.text:
+ZET NARUTO 
He means that everything emits some form of EM radiation. Check out black 
body radiation on google, it explains it further. But to summarise: the 
more heat energy something has, the shorter the EM radiation it produces 
is. Since both infrared and visible light are both forms of EM radiation, 
and infrared has a longer wavelength than visible light we 'glow infrared' 
due to the fact that we're not hot enough.
